forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
Well, there are a few factors that can influence the booting. Just for the record, the updated version of that page is here: [http://tinyempire.co...drismissing.htm](http://tinyempire.com/notes/ntldrismissing.htm "External link")
Similar instructions are given here: [http://www.xxcopy.com/xxcopy33.htm](http://www.xxcopy.com/xxcopy33.htm "External link") Typically a BOOT.INI: [http://support.micro...kb/289022/en-us](http://support.microsoft.com/kb/289022/en-us "External link") has one or more ARCPATH entries, in the form: > multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(***0*** )partition(***1*** )\\***WINDOWS*** ="Microsoft Windows XP Professional" /fastdetect > multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(***disk_number*** )partition(***partition_number*** )\\***SYSTEM_ROOT*** ="Some IRRELEVANT text" \ All of the data (exclusion made for the irrelevant text and options) need to match your previous install. Please also note that it is well possible that the error "\\\system32\\hal.dll" can also be due to an actual missing or corrupted hal32.dll. :wink: You should try making a floppy diskette that can access the internal hard disk, at least in read only mode, in order to understand what is in it. You can use a grub4dos boot diskette to basically check contents of the disk (even if NTFS). The old version grub4dos 0.4.2: [http://sites.google.com/site/grubdos/](http://sites.google.com/site/grubdos/ "External link") contains such a floppy image, otherwise you can use a DOS floppy with (if needed) a NTFS driver, such as NTFS4DOS. Post when you have either of the two ready/working, and I can try and give you some more support. :wink: Wonko
